p: Climate changes at more specific times during vegetation phenology were examined. During the main period of plant growth (late-Mayâ€“June: Fig 2), temperature tended to remain unchanged (Mann-Kendall: z = -0.52, P < 0.30), as found for spring in general, while precipitation tended to increase (Mann-Kendall: z = 1.23, P < 0.11), opposite the spring seasonal value. Therefore, the ratio of precipitation to temperature tended to increase (Mann-Kendall: z = 1.11, P < 0.13) over the period of main plant growth during our study. This indicates reduced evapotranspiration [ 59, 60], which is counter to the annual, Water Year, recharge period, and spring seasonal drying and general warming, and suggests increased annual plant production.
